alert.note: Alert for Daviess; Gibson; Knox; Pike (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 10 at 9:16PM EDT until April 13 at 11:36AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers and locations in southwest Indiana and/or southeast Illinois... Wabash River at Mount Carmel. White River at Petersburg and Hazleton. .Minor flooding of lowland areas continues on the White River at both Petersburg and Hazleton...and on the Wabash River at Mount Carmel. Both rivers have crested and will continue to fall through this week amid dry weather. Flooding is expected to end on the Wabash River at Mount Carmel by Tuesday morning....while ending on the White River at Petersburg Wednesday night...and at Hazleton Friday. Minor flooding primarily impacts local river roads, parks, and agricultural land. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...White River at Petersburg. * WHEN...Until late Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins to flood several Pike County roads. Many of the following county roads begin to flood around this level...east of SR 57 include CR 750N...CR 600N and CR 1000E. Pike county road subject to flooding west of SR 57 include...CR 250 W...CR 400W...CR 675N...CR 700 N...CR 1000w...CR 900W...CR 700W and CR 775W. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Monday /7:30 PM CDT Monday/ the stage was 18.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Monday /7:30 PM CDT Monday/ was 19.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late Wednesday evening and continue falling to 6.2 feet Thursday, April 20. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/ind. This statement will be updated within the next 12 to 24 hours.
